Fields.DialogueText: Kapitän! Al Ana approaching, port side!
@BATTLE
All right, let's have the crew assess what damage has been done.
Evet. I'll have them get right... on....
Kapitän, we have a distress signal coming in.
Is anyone on the radio?
Captain, are you there?
This is the captain speaking. Who is this?
Marco DiMarco, sir.
Well - hello, DiMarco.

Fields.MenuText: What can I do for you?

Fields.DialogueText: Not great, sir. It seems I've gotten into some trouble.
Well, sir, I hate to call in a favor, but I could use your help. I've gotten into some trouble.
Haha, no time for pleasantries, I see. I'm afraid I've gotten into some trouble.
And what would you like me to do?
Well, any chance you could pick me up in Italy?
Kapitän, we're a little behind schedule - but we've finally arrived at La Spezia.
Thank you, Yavuz. Any idea how soon DiMarco will meet us?
I have someone posted to keep an eye out for him, and DiMarco will be directed to us once he arrives.
Good.
So. How much trouble do you think he's in?
I don't think he'd reach out to us unless he was really worried. So, since you ask, I think he's in a lot of trouble.
Ha. You can say that again.

Fields.MenuText: Oh, DiMarco, no, I'm sure everything will be fine.
It's good to see you, DiMarco. I'm just sorry it's under these circumstances.
Ah, here is the troublemaker himself. Glad you made it here safely, DiMarco.

Fields.DialogueText: You keep thinking that, Captain.
Haha, me too, Captain. Me too.
Thank you, Captain. Sorry for pulling you all into this.
We're going to do everything we can to help you out, DiMarco.
Oh, I wasn't aware you were bringing a guest.
My apologies, Miss. This is Giada Natale. She's also wrapped up in the trouble.
Welcome aboard, Signora Natale. We can talk about what's going on later. Why don't the two of you go and rest for now?
Thank you, Captain. I think I remember my way around.
Heh. This should be interesting.
Dikkat! Another enemy fleet approaching, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
Now that we're all settled, I think it's time to hear what's going on. Marco?
Yes, Captain. As you know, I am an inquiry agent, and oftentimes my clientele can edge on being...
Ah, that's one way of putting it.
That's one way of putting it.
Heh, that's one way of putting it...
In any case, my most recent job was for Vincenzo Natale.
Vincenzo Natale. The head of the infamous Neapolitan crime syndicate.
The very one.
Marco, I'm going to make some jumps in logic. Did we just help you smuggle Natale's wife out of the country?
Yes.
Why?
Natale had me tailing his wife because he thought she was having an affair. It didn't take long to find proof she was meeting up with someone.
But it wasn't what it looked like. She was meeting with a man who specializes in creating new identities for people. She was planning on leaving Natale.
It wasn't hard to believe she was going on the run. I mean, we've all heard the rumors of his brutality. I knew I couldn't go back to Natale with what I found.
I also knew if I didn't come back, he'd come looking for me. I told Giada what was going on, and we reached out to you.
Kapitän, I apologize for interrupting. Al Ana approaching - we better get ready.
We'll finish this later. Marco, go hunker down.
Ergh... Let me tell you, I have not missed this.
@BATTLE
Signora Natale, DiMarco has told us you were planning to leave your husband, and he has suggested your husband would react violently if he found out.
I need you to tell us why you're leaving, how you were planning to leave, and anything else that might help us know how to go forward from here.
Please understand, I love my husband. He wasn't like this when we first married. He just wanted us to have a good life.
But then... we had some hard times, and his business changed direction.
It just started with bookmaking, but then he hired enforcers. Then he expanded into other areas... worse areas.
He just became more and more closed off, angrier... more controlling. I couldn't take it anymore. I knew I needed to get out... for my safety.
I started looking for someone who could help me run. I finally found someone, and that's when DiMarco caught me.
How were you going to run?
The man was making me a new identity. Once he got me a new passport, he was going to arrange for me to be set up in America.
Anlıyorum. But that must cost quite a bit. How were you going to pay him?
I... I emptied Vincenzo's account.

Fields.MenuText: Okay. So, you're doing this with style.

Fields.DialogueText: It's the only option I had.
I know, but what else could I do?
I know. I just couldn't think of any other way.
Where's the money now?
With me.
Marco, we're going to have words later about the proper enactment of favors.  But right now, we have more immediate problems.
There's a Morgana approaching, huh?
Evet. DiMarco, look after Bayan Natale, please.
@BATTLE
Heads up, sir. Al Ana approaching.
Thank you, Yavuz. Battle stations!
@BATTLE
Out of one fight and into another. What are we going to do about Giada? Herhangi bir fikrin var mı, Kapitän?

Fields.MenuText: Try to get her away from her extremely violent husband, I would think.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I am. We need to drop her at the nearest port.
We need to drop her as soon as possible, sir.
Respectfully, sir, no. We need to drop her.
I'm surprised you feel so strongly. She needs help; she doesn't have anywhere else to go.
With all that money, I think she could go anywhere she pleases.
You don't trust her?
No. Azıcık bile degil.
Yavuz, it's not as if your trust is readily given. Why don't we hear more of what she planned to do, and we can decide from there?
Yavuz?
You're the Kapitän. Do what seems best to you.
That's not quite the response I was hoping for...
Signora Natale, we would like you to clarify a few details of your story. First of all, how did you withdraw Vincenzo's money without him noticing?
My family owns the bank that holds all of the accounts for Vincenzo's business. I'm one of the officers there.
And how many of those accounts did you empty?
All of them.
That seems like a bit much, don't you think?
You're right, it's more than what was necessary to run - but taking everything meant it would be harder for him to come after me.
Bayan Natale, how old are you?
Excuse me?
How old are you?
I don't see how that's relevant.
Humor me.
And how old is your husband?
What, Kapitän? It's a perfectly normal question.
What's wrong with asking? It's not as if Bayan Natale would have a reason to hide it.
It can't hurt to know. It might help us predict his behavior.
He's 58.
And your plans were to go to America?
Yes, to New York.
Doesn't the Natale family have a significant amount of business in New York? Why move so close to them?
Yes... Like you said, we have associates there. I have friends there who were going to take me in until I could get settled somewhere further west, like Chicago or Detroit.
Yavuz, there's a Morgana ahead. This conversation, interesting as it is, will have to wait.
Fine. Take care, Bayan Natale.
@BATTLE
Ah! The familiar rocking of gunfire. I'll be in a closet somewhere.
Have fun with that.
To battle stations!
@BATTLE
How are you feeling, DiMarco? Seasickness giving you a hard time?
No one thinks you're funny, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: I'll take that as a no...
Haha, you might need some more time in that closet. I don't think you're ready to deal with people yet.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll be fine... give me a moment.
I think Yavuz's trying to get me back for dragging you guys into this. There's so much rocking.
Sorry, Captain. I'll perk up in a bit.
I did come find you for a reason. Giada told me she wasn't able to get her new passport from her guy in Italy. If we want to deposit her anywhere safe, she's going to need one.
What's your suggestion?
I know a guy. The bad news is he's in Nice, but the good news is that he's clean- no ties to the Natales at all. We can trust him to be discreet.
If you drop me off, I can get the passport and get intel on how much progress Vincenzo has made in figuring out where we disappeared to.
Well, you're in luck. Nice is on our patrol route, more or less.
Thank you, Captain.
I have never been so happy to be back on land. How can you live like this?!
DiMarco, it is literally the only life I've ever known.
Haha, I hadn't thought about that. Well, until next time. Keep an ear out for my call.
Will do, DiMarco.

Fields.MenuText: Try not to get into any more trouble.
Stay safe. Keep your head down.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll do my best.
Aye, sir.
Ha.
Yavuz, are we all right?
Evet. Of course. Why do you ask?
I know you disagree with me about how to handle this. I just... I want to make sure you know... Agh, I don't know where I was going with that. Are we good?
We're fine, Kapitän. If you'll stop pestering me with domestic squabbles, I have a war to attend to.
Again, not quite the response I was hoping for.
@BATTLE
Giada? Did you wait out the battle under my desk? Here, let me help you up.
Oh, thank you, Captain. It all started so quickly- I just darted to the closest sturdy thing.
Well, you look fine. No harm done?
No harm done. With you as Captain, I'm sure we're all perfectly safe.

Fields.MenuText: Yavuz might have a few things to say to the contrary...
Sit through a few more battles, and we'll see if your tune doesn't change...

Fields.DialogueText: I do. I've never felt safer.
Yavuz seems to be pretty contrary in general...
Haha, I'm sure you're just being modest.
Ahem.
Oh, Yavuz, hi, um... I was just checking on Giada after the battle. She's fine.
I can see that.
Did you need something?
One of the engineers wants you to have a look at something.
Right. I'll be right there.
@BATTLE
Oh, hi, Yavuz! What are you up to?
It seems self-explanatory...
What?
I'm playing chess.
But you're not playing with anyone.
I'm playing against myself.
Why?
Being my own worst enemy means any other enemy will be easier to handle.
With a mind like that, the Captain's lucky to have you.
What are you insinuating?
I'm sorry, I just assumed the two of you were...
Hayır. We're not.
So the captain's unattached?
Yes, Bayan Natale.
I'm curious, what exactly is the captain's type? I mean, if it's not a girl like you, then...
The Kapitän likes girls who flatter and don't argue - the less opinionated, the better. A girl who's completely helpless and in need of someone to save her, really.
Doing fantastic, sir.
Hello, Captain.
Of course we are! Yavuz was just telling me about self-defeating chess.
...I'll let you two talk.
What were you two talking about when I came in?
I was telling lies.
Er... what?
It's not important. Kapitän, I believe we have a threat on our tail. We had best get ready for battle.
@BATTLE
What are you working on now?
Your obituary.
Ha... What?
Nothing will make Vincenzo stop looking for you like you being dead.
I suppose I can't argue with you there. May I read it?
Evet. Go ahead.
Let's see... Giada Oberti-Natale was born... Wow, you really did your research... uh huh... da da da... Impaled by a rogue support beam?!

Fields.MenuText: You know, you have a positive knack for this. Can you come up with a freakish death for me next?

Fields.DialogueText: It happens more often than you'd think.
What? It's definitive.
Hush.
So, technically, I'm dead now?
After this battle, you will be. Better crawl under the Kapitän's desk again, unless you want this obituary to be real.
@BATTLE
Kapitän! Prepare for enemy contact!
@BATTLE
Captain? Are you in here?
Right here, Giada. I was just putting some books back in place after that battle.
Oh, they're beautiful!
Thank you. If you're interested, you're free to look at them any time.
I might do just that. Are you hungry? I thought you might be, so I brought you something.
Oh, thank you.
Mind if I join you?
Oh... um... of course not. Have a seat.
Oh, you're eating...
You're welcome to join us, Yavuz.
Heh. Hayır tesekkürler. I'm good.
Suit yourself. Before you go, would you hand me that sauce? I accidentally left it on the tray.
AGH! Ack, my dress!
Oh, I'm so sorry! I can be so clumsy sometimes! I'm sure that will wash right out.
I'm going to go take care of this. Excuse me.

Fields.MenuText: Did you... did you do that on purpose?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course!
Evet, Kapitän?
Don't be silly, Kapitän. You know I'm always dropping things. Clumsy me.
*sigh*
Kapitän, one of the maintenance officers has a question and... Oh, Giada, what are you doing in here?
The Captain said I could look at his books any time I like. Isn't that a lovely gesture?
Heh... it's something.
What?
Nothing.
You might want to relocate. We're coming into known enemy territory.
Oh, I'll be fine. The captain's office is perfectly safe.
Oh, Yavuz, there you are. I just finished talking to the maintenance officer, so your "mission" is no longer necessary.
Oh, well, good to know I'm not needed. Great. Hadi hazırlanalım.
@BATTLE
I spy with my little eye... a monster ship who could use an attitude adjustment.
I suppose the fire-control system could be considered your eyes, yes...
@BATTLE
Oh, Yavuz, could you stay back for a moment?
Evet Kapitän?
Are you doing all right?
Why do you ask?
Well.... I hesitate to even bring this up, given what I can anticipate your reaction being... but you've seemed to be kind of... I don't know... upset.... For a while now...
Of course I am.
I'm fine.
Nothing's wrong, Kapitän.
Yavuz, you are clearly upset about something. Anyone could spot it. You always get so weird when you're upset.
I'm not upset.
Yavuz.
I'm not upset! If I sound upset now it's just because you keep insisting I'm upset when I'm not!
Fine. I'll leave you alone.
... I just yelled at the Kapitän... the Kapitän wasn't even being an idiot.
What has gotten into me lately? It seems like everything the Kapitän does makes me angry...
Hello, Yavuz.
Hi...
Look, if you say nothing's wrong, I'll believe you, but you have to admit things have been pretty weird lately.
What? Things haven't been weird. They've just been... It's just... It's just... The tide cycle.
The tide cycle.
Evet. Haven't you noticed it before? Every time the neap tide comes in, I get weird. Like clockwork.

Fields.MenuText: Some visceral part of me thinks I should be squeamish right now.
The tide cycle. That's what you're going with.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, it can be a lot to deal with.
Oh, you definitely should be.
Yes, really, like clockwork.
*ALARM*
... I'll see you on the bridge, Yavuz.
The tide cycle? Honestly, Yavuz, where do you come up with this stuff?
@BATTLE
Okay, Yavuz. I'm going to ask one more time. What is going on? And don't give me that tide cycle excuse, because I asked around, and I got some very weird looks.
So, out with it. What's going on?
Kapitän...
I mean, did I do something? Did I say something?
No...
Is it about Giada? I know you're less than thrilled to have her around.
No. I don't know. I'm just... I'm fine. I apologize for my recent erratic behavior, and I promise I will do better.
Yavuz, I'm not reprimanding you. I'm worried about you.
Honestly, sir, there's no need.

Fields.MenuText: Yavuz, I just want you to be honest with me.
Yavuz, if there's anything I can do...

Fields.DialogueText: I am being honest, sir. I'm fine.
There's nothing to be done, sir. I'm fine.
I do, sir. I'm fine.
I'm probably just feeling a little stir crazy, that's all. You know the feeling, right?
I do.
See, that's all it is. A few good ship battles and I should be as good as new.
@BATTLE
Anyone there?
It's the captain, Marco. You're coming in loud and clear. How's France?
Informative.

Fields.MenuText: But you're displeased with the information?

Fields.DialogueText: Yes. Good, but annoying.
You could say that.
Look, I need to go to Italy to tie up some loose ends. Just keep Giada close, and I'll let you know when I need to be picked up.
Roger that.
Yavuz, could you keep DiMarco company for a moment? I'll be right back.
... Aye, sir.
All right, what's wrong with you?
Ne? What do you mean?
Yavuz, I only needed two words out of your mouth to know something was wrong. What is it? Out with it.
Fair point. I guess I've been upset constantly ever since Giada came aboard. My stomach is always in knots, and I kind of want to punch her and the Kapitän in their faces.
Marco... I think I have feelings for the Kapitän.
...You don't say.
You say that like it's obvious. Is it obvious?
Well, maybe not to the Captain, but to bystanders, uh, definitely, yes.
Yavuz, you know those feelings are a good thing, right?
Evet...
Then why are you all sulky?
Giada is always clinging onto the Kapitän, and she's much more comfortable with these things than I am. I don't really stand a chance. What can I do?
Uh, you can grow up and communicate honestly about what you want like the functioning adult that you are.
Ouch.
Yavuz, give the Captain a reason to believe you care, and tell Giada where she can go.
I'm not sure I can do that.
You're a famed warship, and you're not sure you can confront your feelings?
Well, my specialty has always been evasion...
Er, sorry to interrupt, you two. There's a Morgana ahead. Get ready.
@BATTLE
Hahaha!
Now, that is hilarious!

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad my pain is amusing to you.

Fields.DialogueText: You're too much!
What's wrong with that?
Hahaha, no, it's just... so... pathetic!
Having fun? I could hear you all the way down the hall.
Yavuz... you're all... normal again. What happened?
Like I said, sir, I just needed a good fight.
Battle.
What?
You said all you needed was a few good ship battles.
Oh, I meant a good fight.
Well, hopefully you're still up for ship battles, because that is a Morgana on the horizon.
@BATTLE
Yavuz? Are you in here? Are you playing chess with yourself again?
Actually, I was reading.
The Beaver Coat?
Evet. It's an excellent little German play.
What's it about?
Well, it's a naturalist play, so it's about people acting like real people in realistic but life-altering situations. It's an examination of the human mind.
But, essentially, it's about a thieving woman who manipulates assumptions about gender and crime for her personal gain. Sound familiar?
I'm sure I don't know what you mean.
I'll have to make it clear to you, then.

Fields.MenuText: You know, I don't think I will ever get used to the two of you being in a room together.

Fields.DialogueText: Not at all, Kapitän. Did you need something?
Hello, Kapitän. Did you need something?
You know, I think Bayan Natale and I are actually beginning to understand each other.
Right... well, there's a Morgana ahead.
@BATTLE
DiMarco, are you there?
Captain? Can you hear me?
There seems to be some interference.
Kapitän, Al Ana ahead.
Hold tight, DiMarco. We'll be right back.

Fields.MenuText: You know, unless we decide to drink heavily after we teach this Morgana a thing or two.

Fields.DialogueText: Haha, I'll be right here.
Have one for me, sir.
Please, I'm unforgettable.
@BATTLE
Let's try this again. DiMarco, can you hear us?
Loud and clear, sir.
Great! How's Italy?
Er... Just come pick me up at La Spezia as soon as you can. Please.
That doesn't sound good...
Has Signor DiMarco boarded?
He should be here soon.
Has he said why he needed to go to Italy?
Not yet. I'm curious to hear myself.
Ah, DiMarco, how are you?
Just fine, sir. Giada, could you go get Yavuz, please?
Of course.

Fields.MenuText: Is there a reason you sent Giada out of the room?

Fields.DialogueText: We've been played.
Well, yes, I'm a little peeved right now.
Oh, is there ever.
We need to have a private conversation with Yavuz. And we can't let Giada know about it.
@BATTLE
@BATTLE
Okay, Giada thinks we're doing a routine maintenance inspection after the battle. What's going on, DiMarco?
When I was in France I started hearing rumors, so I checked in with one of my contacts. He said there had been a massive overhaul of the Natale's operation.
We expected that. Vincenzo lost all of his money.
I thought that too, but something seemed off, so I went to Italy. I spoke with members of Vincenzo's posse. Turns out our Signora Natale's been a very bad woman.
I didn't say anything.
She's the one running the operation, isn't she?
There was no mistaking it, was there?
It turns out no one in Vincenzo's posse had ever seen him. Everything anyone knew about him was a story they had heard from someone else.
So, I went to see Vincenzo. He had no idea the crime syndicate existed. It turns out, Giada's been the boss the whole time, operating under her husband's name.
What Vincenzo thought was an affair was actually Giada living a entire double life. He was crushed.
From there, I went to the bank and learned that Giada had actually moved all of the money to New York already.
So, she was ready to separate herself from her husband's image and move the operation into New York.
And we were going to help her do it.
Okay, go ahead.
What do you mean?
You must be dying to say "I told you so." Go ahead.
I'm not dying to say it. I'm just glad Giada doesn't have this hold on you anymore.
Wait, what? Hold? What hold?
She had you wrapped around her finger!
What? No!
Really? She was flirting with you constantly, and you loved it.
I was being nice! Not to mention, I had to take whatever niceness I could get while you spent all that time being weirdly hostile.
I was just hostile because I didn't know how to take you having feelings for Giada!
Giada? Yavuz, I have feelings for you!
You do?
Yes! How could I not?

Fields.MenuText: You're so frustratingly smart and observant. You never let me get away with anything! You're constantly forcing me to be a better person!
You're so amazingly determined and stubborn, and apparently that's what I find attractive!
You're this maddening mixture of tough and sensitive, so I never know what I'm going to get with you, but I turns out I want to take anything you throw at me!

Fields.DialogueText: And you like that?
That's insane. You're insane!
You make it sound like I'm crazy.
Okay, right now we have to take care of whatever that is that's firing at us, but afterward, we're talking about this. Okay? So just... get ready for that.
@BATTLE
@BATTLE
Why are we stopping? Do we have to do repairs or something?
Actually, we're doing a prisoner transport.
Oh, I wasn't aware we carried prisoners. How frightening.
Funny, for a while there we weren't aware of it either. ...Well, Yavuz was.
What do you mean?
Signora Natale, the polizia are here to collect you.
What are you talking about?
It seems Italy isn't a fan of extortion, money laundering, or conspiring to commit murder.
Come on, Signora Natale. It's time to go. There is literally nowhere to run; you're at sea...
You lying bastards!
Stop it.
Ne? Stop what?
Grinning like that.
I can hardly help it, Kapitän.
Well, DiMarco, it was nice to have you aboard again. You're welcome back any time - just try to leave the crime lords at port.
Haha, I think I can manage that, Captain. Lady Yavuz, it was good to see you. I'm glad you chose to fight.
Teşekkür ederim. Or... thank you, DiMarco. Take care.
Chose to fight...? Yavuz, did you go to DiMarco for relationship advice?
He kind of just threw the advice at me.

Fields.MenuText: So we're together because DiMarco gave you a pep talk?
So you took relationship advice from someone who's been divorced twice?

Fields.DialogueText: Essentially, yes. You should thank him.
Huh, I was not aware of that. Does it matter?
He told me to grow up and take Giada down.
Humor aside, I'm glad you took his advice.
Me too. How nice to finally agree on something...
